comparison.title: Algorithm Comparison
comparison.empty: Select algorithms and click on the plot to set a starting point.

explanation.trueHessian: The exact second-order derivatives of the objective function.
explanation.approxInverse: The quasi-Newton approximation to the inverse Hessian, built incrementally using gradient information.
explanation.convergence: As iterations progress, quasi-Newton methods (BFGS, DFP, SR1) improve their approximation of the inverse Hessian, leading to faster convergence near the optimum.

newton.title: Newton's Method
newton.description: Uses the exact Hessian matrix H(x) to compute the search direction: d = -H⁻¹∇f. Provides quadratic convergence but requires computing and inverting the Hessian at each step.

bfgs.title: BFGS
bfgs.description: Builds an approximation Bₖ to the inverse Hessian using only gradient information. Updates the approximation to satisfy the secant condition: Bₖ₊₁yₖ = sₖ.

dfp.title: DFP
dfp.description: The first quasi-Newton method, proposed by Davidon and later developed by Fletcher and Powell. Uses a different update formula than BFGS but achieves similar results.

sr1.title: SR1 (Symmetric Rank-1)
sr1.description: Uses a rank-1 update that can capture negative curvature. Can exactly reconstruct the Hessian for quadratic functions in n steps, but doesn't guarantee positive definiteness.

newton.name: Newton's Method
newton.description: Uses true Hessian matrix for quadratic convergence
